prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Arguments rejected by the Panel—Possibility of transfer under 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a)

para.paratext: Parties have occasionally urged the Panel not to order transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 in order that they might submit motions to transfer for all purposes under § 1404(a). The Panel historically was not willing to defer to transferor courts in this regard.[1] This was especially true where there were more than a few actions.[2] Inasmuch as it is now clearly decided that a transferee court cannot consider a motion for change of venue to itself after transfer by the Panel, there is no reason to advance this motion.[3] In a similar vein, the Panel has specifically declined to consider that the court in which an action is pending might defer to another case as “first-filed.”[4]

More recently, however, the Panel will not only consider the pendency of a motion under 1404(a), it may view a motion under that statute as preferable to transfer by the Panel. Where transfer under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1404(a) hold a reasonable prospect of mooting a decision by the Panel, it may deny transfer. This may be articulated as a matter of the venue transfer destroying the multidistrict nature of the litigation,[5] or that transfer under the venue statute is preferable or that MDL transfer should be “the last solution that parties seek after considered review of all other options.”[6] It is, of course, unlikely that 1404(a) transfer would be a meaningful alternative in a docket with many actions pending in many districts.

Looking forward, the preference for transfer under section 1404(a) may be an appealing option in many MDL dockets. Because the statute limits transfer to a district “where it might have been brought,” there may be few available transferee districts. The Supreme Court's 2017 decisions on personal jurisdiction,[7] coupled with its 2014 Daimler decision,[8] may make it an unusual set of cases that could all be transferred to a common district under 1404(a). In that regard, 1407 regains its advantage of allowing transfer without regard to venue considerations.[9]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See, e.g., In re Mid-Air Collision Near Hendersonville, N. C. on July 19, 1967, 297 F. Supp. 1039 (J.P.M.L. 1969). See also In re Wright Medical Technology, Inc., Conserve Hip Implant Products Liability Litigation, 844 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (J.P.M.L. 2012) (Panel declines to not attempt to distinguish between “meritorious” and “non-meritorious” actions in assessing the complexity of the issues or the number of actions.).

See, e.g., In re Oxycontin Antitrust Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1388 (J.P.M.L. 2004) (transfer under § 1404(a) not sufficient alternative to 1407 transfer in part because of large and growing number of actions).
The inability of a transferee court to transfer cases transferred by the Panel is discussed in § 9:22.
See In re Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) Data Theft Litigation, 461 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2006).

In re Republic Western Ins. Co. Ins. Coverage Litigation, 206 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2002). See also In re Porcine Circovirus (PCV) Vaccine Products Patent Litigation, 655 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (J.P.M.L. 2009).

In re Dollar Tree Stores, Inc., Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) and Wage and Hour Litigation, 829 F. Supp. 2d 1376, 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2011), quoting In re Best Buy Co., Inc., California Song-Beverly Credit Card Act Litigation, 804 F. Supp. 2d 1376, 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2011).

See BNSF Ry. Co. v. Tyrrell, 137 S. Ct. 1549, 198 L. Ed. 2d 36 (2017); TC Heartland LLC v. Kraft Foods Group Brands LLC, 137 S. Ct. 1514, 197 L. Ed. 2d 816 (2017); Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. v. Superior Court of California, San Francisco County, 137 S. Ct. 1773, 198 L. Ed. 2d 395 (2017).
Daimler AG v. Bauman, 134 S. Ct. 746, 187 L. Ed. 2d 624 (2014) (limiting the availability of general jurisdiction over a defendant to states where the defendant is “at home”).
